nodes.bodyText: The unit tests seems to imply this, however I'd like to confirm; this method is only for writing custom properties, right? Since this is a generic JsonBuilder, does it have any sense of what "properties" are? Or is this just for writing any generic subtree of the JSON object?
this is just for "writing  generic subtree of the JSON object", any concerns?

Would this affect the order in which all schema attributes are written, even non-custom properties? e.g. [namespace, name, type, fields] vs [type, fields, name, namespace]. Or are those written individually in the schema encoder? I'm concerned that this would affect the ordering of things that aren't custom properties
it shouldn't. non-customer properties are written using other code. This code only manage the properties, so all properties written as a trunk. shouldn't affect others
This is not a good idea. The jackson codec is used for serializing data on the servers and making this change here will affect performance of services.
Update code ,can you please check? Now I limit the scope of the change so it only applies when writing properties.
space before ?
mapKeyOrdered -> orderMapsByKey
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -213,12 +224,35 @@ public DataList readList(InputStream in) throws IOException
     return parse(_factory.createParser(in), mesg, locationMap);
   }
 
-  public void objectToJsonGenerator(Object object, JsonGenerator generator) throws IOException
+  /**
+   * Convert an object to Json format representation.
+   * @param object the object that needs to be converted
+   * @param generator the generator that could generate Json output based on the object
+   * @param mapKeyOrdered if the object contains map element (which could be nested map), can set this flag to order the
+   *                      map entries in the output according to sorted map key.
+   * @throws IOException
+   */
+  public void objectToJsonGenerator(Object object, JsonGenerator generator, boolean mapKeyOrdered) throws IOException

nodes.bodyText: Do not change public APIs. Keep this one and add the second API
Good catch. Fail to notice it was public

JacksonTraverseCallback -> Traverse.Callback
Avoid implementation details in the java doc

I wouldn't say I totally agree with you in this one. But I made the change according to your suggestion/
The reason is that this method take in "generator" as input parameter in order to return Data.TraverseCallback, this is already very implementation specific and very detailed implementation description. Something unavoidable.
If true, then map elements in the object (can be the object itself or its nested elements) will be sorted by Key in the generated Json.
